[WARD NURSE 1]: Hey, just handing over James Taylor, 42 years old, admitted yesterday with severe tonsillitis. He’s heading to theatre later this morning for a tonsillectomy.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s his current status?
[WARD NURSE 1]: He’s afebrile now, vitals are stable — RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, HR 82. Still has significant throat pain and is nil by mouth in preparation for surgery. ENT reviewed him this morning and confirmed he’s on the list.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Got it. Any IV access?
[WARD NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G in the right forearm — patent and secure. He’s had IV fluids and antibiotics this morning. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[WARD NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert and cooperative, just a bit anxious about the procedure, which is understandable.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Has the pre-op checklist been done?
[WARD NURSE 1]: Yep — checklist complete, consent signed, anaesthetics team has reviewed. Theatre is booked for 11:30 AM. Just keep an eye out for any changes and let the team know if there’s a delay.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need to escalate a concern about Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, currently in bed 5 on the urology ward. He’s been deteriorating clinically — I’m not exactly sure what’s triggering it, but I think he needs a medical review soon, possibly urgently.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s going on?
[NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. A catheter was inserted last night, but over the last few hours he seems to have become more lethargic, tachycardic, and hypotensive. His urine output’s dropped quite a bit — not sure if the catheter’s blocked or if he’s just shutting down.
[DOCTOR]: What are his current vitals?
[NURSE]: BP’s sitting around 88/54, HR about 112, RR 22, SpO₂ 96% on room air, temp 37.9°C. He’s only passed about 40 mL in the last three hours, give or take. His Q‑ADDS is around 7, though I’ll double‑check — it might be 8 depending on the scoring for output.
[DOCTOR]: Any pain or other symptoms?
[NURSE]: He’s got some lower abdominal discomfort — says it’s “tight” more than painful — and a low‑grade fever. He’s a bit confused, which the team on shift earlier didn’t mention, so that’s new. No vomiting that I’ve seen, but he’s refusing fluids and looks a little clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, this morning’s labs: white cell 14.6, CRP 98, creatinine 168 from 102 yesterday, eGFR down to 44 — sorry, I think it’s 44, not 4, but I can confirm. Looks like he might be heading into an acute kidney injury, possibly secondary to infection, obstruction, or both. Micro hasn’t come back yet, but urine looked cloudy.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, thanks. I’ll come and review him now — give me about ten minutes. We may need imaging and probably to escalate to the surgical team if obstruction’s worsening. I’ll decide once I’ve seen him.
[NURSE]: Alright, I’ll keep an eye on him for now and prepare in case you want to transfer or escalate further.

example.text:
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Good morning, Ms. Lopez. I’m Dr. Chen from City Surgical Unit. I’ll get handover from my colleague now, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: This is bed 5, Maria Lopez, 46 years old, under Dr. Singh.
She was admitted yesterday with acute right upper quadrant pain and nausea. An Ultrasound confirmed multiple gallstones with signs of cholecystitis. She’s being transferred for laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: She’s hemodynamically stable. No signs of biliary obstruction. Her pain is controlled with regular analgesia. There have been no changes in her condition overnight. 
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Hi Ms. Lopez, can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Maria Lopez.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Thank you. I’ll also check your wristband. That matches.
Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: Just a little soreness, but it’s better than yesterday.
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Vital signs this morning is BP: 124/76, HR: 82 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 37.2
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: I’ll confirm that in the chart.
What’s her current medication chart?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]:
She’s currently receiving: IV ceftriaxone 1g daily for suspected cholecystitis, IV metronidazole 500mg TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID orally, Ondansetron 4mg IV PRN for nausea, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr and has been NBM since admission
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Any relevant past medical history?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]: Yes: Hypertension (on amlodipine 5mg daily), No diabetes, No previous surgeries, No known liver disease
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: So, the plan is transfer her for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. No outstanding investigations?
[OUTGOING_DOCTOR]:  Bloods from yesterday: WCC: 11.2, CRP: 45, LFTs: mildly elevated ALT 68, ALP 110, bilirubin is normal, Renal function is normal, her Electrolytes are within range.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]:  Ms. Lopez, is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[INCOMING_DOCTOR]: Alright, I’ll see you again shortly once you’re settled in.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]:
Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, transferring to your ward post-procedure. He had a urethral dilation and bladder washout under general anaesthetic due to acute urinary retention and suspected obstructive uropathy.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: It went smoothly. No complications in theatre. He’s now stable but needs close monitoring due to recent deterioration pre-op—he was hypotensive and oliguric. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.
[WARD_NURSE]: Vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 112/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 37.4°C, Urine output: 120 mL in the last hour
[WARD_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes: he has an IDC draining with clear urine, an IV cannula in left forearm, there are No infusions running currently and Oxygen via nasal prongs earlier, now weaned off
[WARD_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, Gentamicin IV stat dose given in theatre, PRN oxycodone and IV fluids were running intra-op, now ceased.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, he’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background and has limited English. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds. His son is bilingual and will be visiting later today.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Any outstanding tasks?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s due for post-op obs in 30 minutes, and the IDC needs to be monitored closely. Urology team will review later today. He’s alert but tired.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll get him settled and continue monitoring.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Great. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Singh, I need to escalate a concern about Mrs. Joan Wallace, bed 7. She’s Day 5 post-abdominal surgery and was awaiting PEG insertion, but she’s now showing signs of clinical deterioration.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s happening?
[NURSE]: She’s become increasingly hypotensive and tachycardic, and her respiratory rate is elevated. She’s also confused, which is new. Her urine output has dropped, and she’s looking pale and clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Do you have her latest vitals?
[NURSE]: Yes: BP: 86/52, HR: 118 bpm, RR: 26, SpO?: 94% on 4L nasal prongs, Temp: 38.2°C, Urine output: 30 mL over the last 3 hours and Q-ADDS score: 8
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, from this morning her WCC: 15.4, CRP: 122, Creatinine: 168, Lactate: 3.1
She’s likely heading into sepsis or acute kidney injury.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll come and review her immediately. We may need to escalate to ICU for closer monitoring and support.
[NURSE]: Understood. I’ll prepare for potential transfer and notify the bed manager.
[NURSE (to BED MANAGER)]: Hi, I’m calling regarding Mrs. Joan Wallace, bed 7. She’s deteriorating post-abdominal surgery and may require ICU admission. The doctor is reviewing her now, but I wanted to flag the need for a potential ICU bed.
[BED MANAGER]: Thanks for the heads-up. I’ll check availability and hold a bed provisionally. Please confirm once the doctor makes the decision.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll keep you updated.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Lee, I need you to review Ms. Margaret Doyle in bed 7. She’s an 82-year-old patient who had an unwitnessed fall in her room about 45 minutes ago. She hit her head on the bedside cabinet and has a visible occipital hematoma.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s her current condition?
[NURSE]: She’s alert but drowsy. Her GCS is 14—she opens eyes to voice, is confused, and obeys commands. She’s complaining of a headache and mild nausea. No vomiting so far.
[DOCTOR]: Any neuro obs or vitals?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’ve started ½-hourly neuro obs. Her latest set: GCS: 14 ,BP: 132/78, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 36.8°C, SpO?: 97% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + nausea + age)
[DOCTOR]: Any bloods done?
[NURSE]: Yes, we drew bloods post-fall. FBC shows: Hb: 122, WCC: 8.6, Platelets: 210, INR: 1.1 Creatinine: 75, She’s not on anticoagulants.
[DOCTOR]: Any other injuries?
[NURSE]: No other obvious trauma. No limb pain or deformity. She mobilised with assistance post-fall but was unsteady.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. We’ll need a CT head to rule out intracranial bleeding. Can you keep neuro obs going and notify me of any GCS drop or vomiting?
[NURSE]: I’ll book the CT and continue neuro obs. I’ll escalate if her Q-ADDS increases or if she becomes more confused

[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old patient admitted with a urinary tract infection. She’s deteriorated over the last few hours.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: She’s has become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered the escalation. She’s also reporting increased confusion compared to her baseline.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: Her BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion).
[DOCTOR]:Has she had any recent bloods or urine cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes, bloods were taken this morning. WCC is 14.2, CRP is 98. Creatinine is slightly up at 102. Urine sample sent, awaiting results.
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No, she doesn’t currently have a cannula. We’ll need to insert one.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. What’s her allergy status?
[NURSE]: She has a documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling reported previously.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her current medication chart?
[NURSE]: She’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, no antibiotics started yet due to allergy—awaiting review.
[DOCTOR]: Alright. I’ll assess her now and likely start IV ceftriaxone and IV gentamicin, given the allergy. We’ll also need to insert a cannula and consider transfer to the acute medical unit if her condition worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll prepare for the cannula and notify the AMU team if needed.
[DOCTOR]: Let me know if her Q-ADDS score increases or if she becomes more confused.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Reid in bed 3. He’s a 79-year-old patient with limited mobility due to a recent stroke. He has a stage 2 pressure injury on his sacrum that requires dressing today.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. No slough or necrosis, but the area is red and moist. No signs of infection at this stage. The wound was last dressed yesterday with Mepilex Border, and it’s due for review and redressing this morning.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: His Waterlow score is 20, so he’s at very high risk. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’ve been repositioning him every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring or interventions?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has: IDC in place – draining clear urine, last emptied 2 hours ago, an IV cannula in right forearm – patent, no fluids running currently, Regular skin checks and documentation in the wound chart, his Pain score this morning was 2/10, no analgesia required
[Incoming Nurse]: Any allergies?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll check the wound, redress with Mepilex Border, and continue pressure care and monitoring.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following a recent pneumonia admission. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her right hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with no signs of infection. There’s mild erythema around the edges. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended continuing with Allevyn Gentle Border dressing.
[Incoming Nurse]: How often does it need changing?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Every 3 days unless soiled or lifting. The next dressing change is due on Friday. We’re documenting progress in the wound chart and taking weekly photos for review.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re repositioning her every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other relevant care?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes:  she has No IV access currently, her Oral intake is adequate, there’s No IDC, but she is continent of urine and bowels, Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required, Skin integrity checks are ongoing, no other areas of concern
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue the pressure care, monitor the wound, and follow the dressing schedule.

[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago following a manic episode. She’s now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder and is being discharged today. I’d like to arrange home supports to help her transition safely.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current situation?
[NURSE]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband is supportive but understandably overwhelmed. He’s asked for help managing the household while Emily stabilises. She’s currently well but still adjusting to the diagnosis.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What kind of supports do you think she’ll need?
[NURSE]: She’ll benefit from: Domestic assistance (light cleaning, laundry, meal prep), Childcare support during the day, especially for the younger children, Mental health outreach for medication adherence and mood monitoring, Education for the family around bipolar disorder and crisis planning. Possibly pet care support if her condition fluctuates
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: No current risks identified. She’s engaging well, has insight, and is compliant with treatment. Her husband is aware of early warning signs and has contact details for crisis support.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What’s her medication plan?
[NURSE]:
She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg – not used in the last 48 hours, she’ll need regular lithium level monitoring and follow-up with the community mental health team.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. I’ll organise a home support package and liaise with the mental health team and family services.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything further from the ward team.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Joan Ellis in bed 2. She’s an 81-year-old patient admitted with a urinary tract infection and worsening confusion. She’s currently alert but disoriented and has been incontinent of both urine and bowels during the shift.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—based on confusion, elevated temperature, and increased respiratory rate. Latest observations are BP: 132/78, HR: 94 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.3°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, she is Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she on any monitoring charts?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, a Fluid Balance Chart – she’s had ~900 mL oral intake today, and incontinent of urine twice. A Bowel Chart – opened bowels once this morning, loose stool and a Falls Risk Chart – high risk due to confusion and mobility issues.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current injuries, but she’s at risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about hygiene?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She’s had a full wash this morning, including peri-care. She’ll likely need another wash later due to incontinence. Continence aids are in use.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No IV access currently. She’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily – given this morning, PRN lorazepam 0.5 mg – not required today
No known allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring, update the charts, and assist with hygiene as needed.

[NURSE 1]: Hey, I’m handing over Sarah Nguyen, 29 years old, came into ED earlier today with acute abdominal pain — mainly in the right lower quadrant. She’s currently awaiting surgical review.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s her current status?
[NURSE 1]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.8°C, HR 88, BP 118/76, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air. Pain is sitting at 6/10, managed with IV analgesia. She’s nil by mouth pending review.
[NURSE 2]: Any imaging done?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, she’s had an abdominal ultrasound — inconclusive. CT abdomen is booked for this afternoon. Bloods show mild leukocytosis, CRP elevated. Urine is clear, pregnancy test negative.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yep, 20G in the left antecubital fossa — patent. She’s had IV fluids and analgesia. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and coping well. Just anxious about the possibility of surgery.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Anything else I need to follow up?
[NURSE 1]: Just keep an eye on her pain and nausea. Surgical team should be around shortly. Let me know if anything changes.

[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home after an argument with his partner.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He arrived via ambulance, drowsy but rousable. He’s currently confused, slurred speech, and intermittently agitated. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, but his SpO? is sitting around 92%. He’s a smoker, and his respiratory rate is slightly depressed at 10–12 breaths per minute.
[Paramedic]: Any vitals or Q-ADDS score?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, latest observations: BP: 118/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 12, Temp: 36.5°C, SpO?: 92% on 2 L O?, GCS: 13 and a Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to RR, SpO?, confusion, and overdose)
[Paramedic]: Any IV access or treatment started?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm, patent. We’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and drawn bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. Activated charcoal was not given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[Paramedic]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner and has been in a verbal altercation prior to the overdose. He has no known mental health diagnosis, but this appears to be a first-time overdose. He has no children at home but reports high alcohol use and smoking daily.
[Paramedic]: Any plans for transfer?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he’s being transferred to the medical ward for monitoring and possible N-acetylcysteine infusion pending paracetamol levels. Mental health team will review once medically stable.
[Paramedic]: Okay, I’ll update the receiving team and ensure safe transfer.

[NURSE 1]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lee, 64 years old. He’s on the ward post-lobectomy and currently has a left-sided ICC in situ. It’s due to come out today.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current status of the ICC?
[NURSE 1]: ICC has been on free drainage. Output over the last 24 hours is minimal — around 20 mL serous fluid. No air leak noted. Chest X-ray this morning shows good lung expansion. Surgical team reviewed and gave the okay for removal.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He’s had some mild discomfort around the insertion site, but it’s well managed with regular paracetamol. No signs of infection — site is clean and dry.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — patent and due for review tomorrow. He’s currently on oral meds only.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the med chart. Anything due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on regular analgesia and a stool softener. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and understands the plan. He’s a bit anxious about the ICC removal, so just reassure him and let him know we’ll use local anaesthetic.
[NURSE 2]: Will do. I’ll prep the trolley and notify the team once it’s out.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Bennett. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Bennett. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rachel Bennett.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Rachel Bennett in Bed 2, Room 9, aged 52, under Dr. Wallace, Oncology Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Rachel, I’m Priya, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’re going through a lot right now, and I’m here to support you. Is it okay if we talk for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, please. I’ve been struggling a bit.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I know chemotherapy can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You mentioned concerns about work and home—can you tell me a bit more about what’s been difficult?
[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so. I just don’t know where to start.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s okay—I'll walk you through it. You’re not alone in this, and we’ll make sure you have the support you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check back in shortly, Ms. Bennett, and coordinate with Priya and Dr. Wallace’s team. Please use the call bell if you need anything.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Nguyen. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Nguyen. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Linh Nguyen.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Linh Nguyen in Bed 3, Room 5, aged 34, under Dr. Patel, Psychiatry Registrar.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Nguyen presented yesterday following suicidal ideation and low mood. She was brought in by her sister after expressing thoughts of self-harm. She has no current injuries. Observations have remained stable overnight. She’s alert, tearful at times, and has engaged minimally with staff.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: A mental health review is scheduled for this morning. A social worker has also been involved to support psychosocial needs and coordinate with family. Her sister and mother are present and have requested to be involved in care planning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Linh, I’m Amina, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’ve been going through a really difficult time. Would it be okay if we talked for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I want to make sure you feel safe and supported. You mentioned feeling overwhelmed—can you tell me a little about what’s been happening?
[PATIENT]: I just feel like I can’t cope anymore. Everything’s too much.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: I’m really sorry you’re feeling this way. You’re not alone, and we’re here to help. Your sister and mum are here and want to support you. Would you be comfortable if we invited them in to talk together?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Okay. We’ll also work with Dr. Patel and the mental health team to make sure you have a plan in place before discharge—whether that’s follow-up care, counselling, or community support. We’ll take it one step at a time.
SISTER]: Linh, we’re here for you. We didn’t know how bad things were, but we want to help however we can.
[MOTHER]: We love you. We’ll do whatever it takes to support you.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you both. We’ll work together to make sure Linh has the right care and support moving forward.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Fraser. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s alright.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Fraser. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Andrew Fraser.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you and your date of birth? 
[PATIENT]: Twenty-third of August 1958. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great and your URN on that armband says 893745 that matches your chart. So Mr Fraser is under the cardiothoracic surgeon covering this list - not sure who.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday for a planned aortic valve replacement due to severe aortic stenosis. He’s currently stable, nil by mouth, and awaiting theatre — I think the procedure’s still set for this afternoon, though final time hasn’t been confirmed yet. Pre‑op bloods and ECG were done and look okay from what I saw, but anaesthetics still need to recheck his potassium levels. Consent’s signed and documented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on his regular cardiac medications — they were reviewed by the anaesthetics registrar this morning, or possibly one of the fellows. No chest pain or shortness of breath that he’s mentioned overnight. Vitals all fine — around baseline. He’s aware of the procedure and quite anxious, understandably; I reassured him but might be worth chatting again before transfer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Fraser, how are you feeling this morning? Any discomfort or anything worrying you?
[PATIENT]: Just nervous, really. No pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Of course. His wife’s planning to come in later today — she wasn’t sure what time yet. Theatre team should ring the ward once they’ve finalised scheduling, but I haven’t heard back this morning. He’s got family contact details in the chart if anyone needs to update them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the surgical team and confirm timing when possible. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing soon, but the coordinator’s around if anything changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ll come back shortly to check your obs and review your chart, Mr. Fraser.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Ms. Lily Harper, 24 years old. Lily, this is Nurse Tessa, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Lily, nice to meet you. I’ll be checking in on you regularly and helping with your care today.
[PATIENT]: Hi. Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lily was admitted yesterday with bradycardia secondary to an eating disorder—her HR dropped to 38 bpm overnight. She’s now in CCU for cardiac monitoring. She’s alert and oriented but fatigued and intermittently dizzy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her current status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: HR is sitting around 42–45 bpm, sinus bradycardia on telemetry. BP is 92/58, RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, Temp 36.2. She’s on Q-ADDS—scoring 5 due to HR and low-normal BP, so we’re doing hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—20G in the left forearm, patent. No IV fluids running currently, but we’ve kept the line in for access if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on thiamine and multivitamins orally, and PRN lorazepam for anxiety. No cardiac meds charted at this stage. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s her intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’ve started a strict food and fluid chart. Dietitian has reviewed and started a re-feeding plan—small, frequent meals. She’s eating slowly but has managed about 50% of her breakfast and lunch today. We’re monitoring for refeeding syndrome—daily bloods are being done.
[PATIENT]: I’m trying to eat, but it’s hard.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay, Lily. We’ll support you through it. Just let me know if you feel unwell or overwhelmed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s also on daily ECGs and electrolyte monitoring. Psych team has been consulted and will review again tomorrow. She’s been cooperative but very anxious.
[DOCTOR]: (enters briefly) Just confirming—Lily is for continued cardiac monitoring and nutritional support. Please escalate if HR drops below 35 or if she becomes symptomatic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue Q-ADDS, monitor intake, and keep an eye on her cardiac rhythm and electrolytes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, food chart, and med chart.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cindy. I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover with Sam before he finishes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 1, Cindy Benedictos, under Dr. Smith. She came in for management of diabetes and high cholesterol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How high did her blood sugars Go? what was her cholesterol level?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The blood sugars were running at 14-16mmol and her cholesterol level is 7.4 so both high. She was seen by the team today and they adjusted her insulin doses again—details are in the chart, and she has been started on a statin. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll review the med chart after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Because Her BGLs have been fluctuating. We’re doing QID plus PRN levels.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are there any significant highs or lows noted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Variable but the insulin is helping to bring the level down it has been documented on the BGL sheet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on daily bloods. The diabetes educator is booked for tomorrow at 2:30 p.m.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have today’s bloods been sent?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, taken and sent this morning we are still waiting for the results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Cindy is self-caring—she self-administers her insulin with a little supervision.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Cindy, are you comfortable continuing to do your insulin with me double-checking?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s what I’ve been doing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any allergies we should be aware of?
[PATIENT]: I'm allergic to penicillin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The team is planning to discharge her early next week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye on the plan and diabetes educator's notes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise, all her observations have been within normal limits.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: okay great. Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We still need to send a urine test off, the form is in her chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. Cindy, I’ll come back shortly to check your next BGL and see if you need anything before breakfast.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Maria. We’re just going to do your bedside handover with the day nurse now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Maria, I’ll be looking after you today. Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Maria Clemens.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Maria, 79 years old, under Dr. Chanson. She came in with shortness of breath on exertion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Goals of care: NFR not for resus and not for MET, as per the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay is that filed in her chart?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. She has multiple allergies (documented on the chart and band). She’s on regular inhaler puffers and a high dose of prednisolone.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s having daily random capillary BGLs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll make sure the BGL is checked today and meds given per chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mobility-wise, she walks independently with a wheely walker.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I manage fine with it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s awaiting team review and an OT review; physio is ongoing.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable. Noted nail changes on assessment. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Maria, how’s your breathing right now — any shortness of breath at rest?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay while I’m sitting. Worse when I walk.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye on that and pace activities.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan is to continue regular puffers and prednisolone, daily random BGLs, await medical team and OT reviews, continue physio, mobilise with the wheely walker as tolerated.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll ensure allergy precautions are in place and the call bell is within reach.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else you need before we finish, Maria?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Christina. I’m the day nurse, Sam. I’ll just get handover from Taylor here at your bedside if that’s okay.
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Christina. Bed 5, Christina Davis, who is 29 years old, under Dr. Mills. She originally presented with vomiting and was diagnosed with pneumonia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s pregnant, and she mentioned she has a 3-year-old daughter. She’s been coughing, particularly after talking.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Right.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on oral antibiotics. Observations have been stable throughout my shift, with a QADDs of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues overnight? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, nothing else to note.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Christina, how are you feeling now? Okay to speak or would you prefer short questions?
[PATIENT]: Talking makes me cough more.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Understood. Any nausea at the moment?
[PATIENT]: No, just the cough.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Taylor, any pending tests or consults?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None pending at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for the morning is to continue oral antibiotics as charted, keep observations going, minimize long conversations to reduce cough triggers, and call us if you feel more short of breath or the cough worsens.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve documented the stable obs and that she’s tolerating care.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Christina, I’ll come back shortly with your medications and to recheck your observations. Is the call bell is within reach?
[PATIENT]: Yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Taylor. Have a good rest.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Bye, Christina.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Benjamin. I'm taking over your care from the night nurse my name is Greg. Is it okay if we do your handover here at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Benjamin. So, this is Benjamin Lincoln 51 years old, under Dr T. Lenny. He was admitted with a query acute kidney injury.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Past history includes diabetes and heartburn. He’s for a renal ultrasound at some point today, and a renal biopsy on Thursday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye out for the ultrasound time and make sure you’re ready to go, Benjamin.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was febrile last night, up to 37.6 but he’s been afebrile on my shift. Other observations seem ok.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:And you’ve been up and about?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Didn't really have to get up at night so unsure.
[PATIENT]: I’ve been walking around a bit, yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Excellent. Any concerns right now—pain, nausea, anything you want us to know about?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay at the moment.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Benjamin, I’ll check your obs shortly and keep you updated about the ultrasound time. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.
